Description: A segmented pottery dish made from coarse red silt clay, with traces of a red slip or wash on the exterior. The fabric was tempered with chaff but has cracked extensively on firing, especially the thick base. There is a one circular inner compartment, the sides of which are the tallest part of the whole vessel. This is surrounded by a circular outer compartment which has been divided into three approximately equal parts by thin partitions, modelled by hand.
Curator's comments: Very similar, if not the same, piece published from Naukratis, dated 7th to 5th century BC (Hogarth et. al. 1905, 125, fig. 5). See also British Museum 1888.0601,736 and 1546.

Parallels: Cf. Defernez, C., La céramique d’époque perse à Tell el-Herr: étude chrono-typologique et comparative, CRIPEL Suppl. 5, vol. 2, Lille, 2003, pl. 2, no. 6 and vol.1, (2001), 52; Aston, D.A., 1990, ‘Stadt und Tempel von Elephantine 17/18 Grabungsbericht: Keramikkomplex 17805A’, MDAIK 46, (1990), 234, no. 17805A, 11, fig. 13.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (IB.023)
